items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall within the catchment. This information is correct as of 15:30pm on Wednesday 2nd October. The causeway at Earith has approximately 43 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 120 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 103 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Thursday 3rd October 2024.

items.message:
River levels have fallen but some water remains on the moors, low lying land and roads may still be under flood water, so this flood alert remains in force.
We have opened the sluice gate to the Parrett Relief Channel and are pumping when river levels allow. We also continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels.
Little rainfall is forecast over the next few days, so we hope to remove this flood alert soon.
Avoid driving, walking or cycling through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 03/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 15:15 on 02/10/24 and 4.74 mAOD at 03:45 on 03/10/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 250 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 03/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 03/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Crane, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Talbot Road; Percy Road; Napier Road; Haliburton Road; Eve Road; Northcote Road footbridge.

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels.

This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 03/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:

We do not expect to see significant impacts from the high tide this afternoon (Wednesday 2 October).
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

We will be closely monitoring the situation, and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 03/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Colwick and Clifton Bridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues to be possible today, 02/10/24.
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including communities near to the River Trent, Queens Drive Park and Ride and Stoke Lane at Stoke Bardolph, Caythorpe road and Hoveringham road, and cellars of low-lying properties at Cavendish Bridge.   
No further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday, 03/10/24.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 03/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Rother
items.message:
River levels are beginning to fall across the catchment and are anticipated to fall throughout today, Wednesday 2nd October 2024. 

Levels remain high in Woodhouse Ings. Our operatives continue to monitor the situation at the Ings and our pumping operations are continuing.

No further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days and we are continuing to closely monitor the situation.

Surface water is likely to affect low spots on roads; take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 9pm on Wednesday 2nd October 2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Rother at Woodhouse Mill
items.message:
This flood warning remains in force due to high river levels following Monday's heavy and persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk include Woodhouse Mill and properties on Furnace Lane and Retford Road. 

River levels at the Woodhouse Ings regulator have levelled and are dropping slowly. Levels upstream at Killamarsh and Meadowgate have been continuing to fall.

With no further significant rainfall forecast over the next few days, levels at Woodhouse are expected to continue to fall today, Wednesday 2nd October, into tomorrow, Thursday 3rd October. 

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not drive through floodwater. To report flooding, call our Incident Hotline on 0800 80 70 60.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message as the situation changes. This message will be updated by 21:30 on 2nd October 2024.

items.message:

Flooding may affect properties and roads in the Temple Mill to Sheepy Magna areas including Sibson Mill, Lovetts Bridge and Sheepy Parva.
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday morning 03/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers and call 999 if in immediate danger.
Avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/10/24, or as the situation changes.
